blog.description: I'm Devyn, but I also go by Artemis. She/Her. 21. Not Straight™. In love with Critical Role, everything by JRR Tolkien, The X-Files, Marvel, Merlin, Star Trek, and Hawaii Five-0. Multifandom Mess. I write fanfiction on AO3 as ConsultingFangirl/DestinyWolfe.

summary: DnD Beyond is pretty dang cool. But its greatest flaw, one that HAS to be resolved by Sam or Liam, or whoever wins the DnD...
body:
DnD Beyond is pretty dang cool.

But its greatest flaw, one that HAS to be resolved by Sam or Liam, or whoever wins the DnD Beyond Presidency, is that the thumbnail icons must be made bigger!

We deserve visible pictures of our characters!

blog.name: mmmthornton
blog.title: Mmmary
blog.description: 29 years old lesbian living in Boston working for a tech company. Allegedly a writer at one point. Working on improving my mental health so you'll see depression posting on here in spades. Not transphobic but on at least one TERF list so at the risk of sounding like an edgelord, follow at your own risk. If you like reading entire essays in tagview, you've come to the right place. No porn or kink blogs.

tags: literally this iiiis taken directly from my life when i lived with Colin
summary: I got to the part of Critical Role where Molly and Beau trip their asses off and I'm screaming internally because dropping...
body: I got to the part of Critical Role where Molly and Beau trip their asses off and I’m screaming internally because dropping hallucinogens and going for a walk outside is actual lesbian bi solidarity.

title: Intelligence (Beau’s Many Crimes)
body:
A little something for Beau Week 2019 prompt - Childhood

Dusted off my rusty writing skills to contribute something for my favourite monk. 

(Warning for references of violence / abuse.)

…

Beau has always been smart.

It’s one of the things that got her in trouble.

 …

Beau knows she is a disappointment to her parents even before she understands the words.

But she likes words. She absorbs them like a sponge.

Remembering everything ever said to her.

Remembering everything spoken in her presence.

 …

Father doesn’t know what to make of an intelligent child.

Daughter’s should not be smart.

Daughter’s should do as they are told.

Father doesn’t like his five-year-old daughter correcting him.

A daughter must never talk back to her father… even if she is right.

Mother does not know what to make of her either.

Mother is not intelligent.

Mother only cares about gowns and jewels and gossip.

Mother is the perfect woman; the perfect wife… Almost perfect. She could not bear Father a son.

If Beau had been a boy, it would be different. A son could learn the books and grow to manage the estate.

But she is not a son and five-year-old Beau knows this is the worse crime of all.

But talking too much is a crime as well and would lead to Father reaching for his belt.

Young Beau soon found herself faltering on every other word, terrified that the next one would be the wrong one and be followed by violence.

She learnt to play at being forgetful.

She learnt it was safer to get things wrong.

She learnt to be a liar.

She was intelligent after all.

 …

Beau does not like to be still.

Father does not approve and calls her boisterous.

This is her third crime.

A daughter should be seen and not heard.

A daughter should preferably not even be seen.

Mother does not care for a fidgeting child.

A daughter should sit quietly and embroider.

A daughter should sit straight in her corset and gown.

A daughter should be a fragile flower awaiting to be plucked by the perfect man.

Beau cannot be the person her mother is. It is almost painful to be forced to sit and do nothing. She wants to run and dance and climb and play.

Ten-year-old Beau is also beginning to see that the smile of a pretty girl was much more appealing than that of a greasy young man.

In a misjudged moment she tells her mother this.

Father came to her that night and violence followed.

A good daughter wants a husband.

Beau does not.

Her fourth crime.

Ten-year-old Beau learns to pretend to be a good daughter.

Ten-year-old Beau lets lies fall from her lips like water until even she loses track.

Lying keeps her safe.

She is intelligent after all.

 …

When she was thirteen Beau came to a realisation.

Father wasn’t always right.

Knowing that made her question every decree ever laid out to her.

It had come as a shock. 

It also made her very angry. 

An anger that would never quite leave her.

When she was thirteen Beau also realised how much her mother hated her life.

How much her Mother hated Father.

How much her Mother resented that he had control of her families money and her families estate.

All Mother had in the world were her gowns and her jewels and her gossip and her ungrateful daughter.

Her mother had surrender.

Thirteen-year-old Beau realised she would never let herself surrender to that kind of unhappiness.

She started breaking the rules, just to see what would happen.

Would sneaking out of the house be worse than being trapped inside it’s stifling walls?

Turns out the answer was no.

Would drinking alcohol poison her?

Well at first it tasted foul, but the buzz she got took away some of the fear and it felt good to be brave. The hangover in the morning sucked, but the pain was nothing compared to that brief moment of escape.

Would kissing a pretty girl bring shame on her family?

Well the first girl wasn’t all that pretty and charged her two copper, but her lips were soft even if her breath tasted of stale beer. The second girl charged a silver and they shared a bed as well.

Father found out and violence followed but Beau knew where her heart belonged, and Father wasn’t right about this either.

Maybe some of the rules Beau broke shouldn’t have been broken. Maybe people got hurt.

But Beau had been forced into a tight ill-fitting box her whole life and freedom, like wine, is intoxicating.

 …

It ended in violence, like always.

But this time it wasn’t her father’s fist striking her. Dark robed figures grabbed her, pulled a hood over her eyes. Punched hard in a way that stopped her from moving.

Father would send his intelligent daughter to a library as a punishment… something else for him to get wrong.

tags: i stan a group of dumbshits
summary:
Yasha: *sprints towards the giants*
Fjord: *running after her* Shit, we're doing this? YOLO!
Beau: *darting after them* Dairon...
body:
Yasha: *sprints towards the giants*

Fjord: *running after her* Shit, we’re doing this? YOLO!

Beau: *darting after them* Dairon said wait but Dairon’s not here.

Yasha: *sprints towards the giants*

Fjord: *running after her* Shit, we’re doing this? YOLO!

Beau: *darting after them* Dairon said wait but Dairon’s not here.

Beau: *darting after them* Dairon said wait but Dairon’s not here.

Yasha: *sprints towards the giants*

Fjord: *running after her* Shit, we’re doing this? YOLO!

Beau: *darting after them* Dairon said wait but Dairon’s not here.

summary: i’ve been keeping up w critrole since like feb last year but i was Today years old when i learned that laura and liam aren’t,...
question: i’ve been keeping up w critrole since like feb last year but i was Today years old when i learned that laura and liam aren’t, like, actually twins. i just kind of? assumed? because everyone kept calling them the twins early in c2. anyway how was your day
answer: Listen Laura and Liam are so in sync that I refuse to accept that they aren’t soul twins, connected by something beyond blood, maybe from another lifetime.

summary: caleb and nott being the rural farm kids of the group? like maybe knowing any weird relatable agriculture tips, or talking with...
question: caleb and nott being the rural farm kids of the group? like maybe knowing any weird relatable agriculture tips, or talking with caduceus or yeza about the magical properties of obscure plants and stuff? only if you're interested of course! :D
answer:
BUDDY FRIEND PAL I owe you my life. I know fuck all about agriculture but I do have chickens so here’s the weirdly angsty drabble wherein Nott, Caleb and Yeza talk about countryside life and owning hens with some relatively tragic subtext.

Set in, like, episode 58??

The biting chill was perhaps, of everything they’d encountered in Xhorhas, the one thing that Nott found the most unfamiliar, the most unsettling. Maybe it was odd, that it was the wind and the spitting rain in the air that felt alien to her here, rather than the great stone giants that traipsed through the streets; the strange voices and languages, guttural, that surrounded them; the sky that stayed dark and star-dappled no matter how many times Caleb muttered that it was noon; the fact that her hair was tied back and her shoulders exposed, sallow and green but somehow inconspicuous, the hostile looks and curious glances passing over her and onto her friends. (Maybe she liked that. Just a bit, just maybe.)

But when she closed her eyes and gripped Yeza’s hand, the chill was the thing that didn’t go away. She had felt it too, back when they first travelled North all those months ago, the tangible sting that was knowing, more than just knowing, that she was far, far from home. Felderwin was warm, tucked safely away with only one hard, cold winter she could call to memory.

But she didn’t want to think about that.

Glancing over at her husband, she saw he was gazing off at something in the distance, distracted. She watched him as they walked, his head twisting this way and that, with his mouth slightly open, as if slowly processing each and every little detail.

They came up to the door of the inn, and his attention refocused as she gave his arm a fond tug. “What were you so distracted by, hun?”

“Hm?” He replied, looking at her with a puzzled expression as they entered into the warm interior, shuffling forward and seating themselves at an empty table.

The rest immediately broke out into discussion about something or other, while she turned to Yeza again and said “You kept looking around, like you were a house cat seeing the outside world for the first time or something. It was cute.”

She noticed Caleb’s head perk up out of the corner of her eye as soon as she said the word ‘cat’ (of course), and Yeza flushed slightly.

“Oh, it just isn’t very often I leave Felderwin, let alone visit a place like this, or, well, it isn’t really visiting. I mean, I’m scared of literally everyone here but I guess it’s also overwhelming… in a good way?” he looked at her and smiled, “though you’re probably more used to it than I am, after all your travels.”

Before Nott could reply, Caleb chimed in. smiling, “I understand how you feel. I’m from a small town also, but I remember -” he faltered slightly, as if troubled by a memory he couldn’t quite recall, “I remember what it was like going to Rexxentrum for the first time. You described the feeling well, friend. Overwhelming in a good way.”

Yeza smiled back, albeit awkwardly. Every one of their interactions were equal parts painful and endearing to watch; she should have expected this.

“Why are all my favourite people total nerds?” She muttered quietly, before Beau shifted to join the conversation which she had apparently been listening into this entire time.

“Yeah, you and No- uh, Veth, are sort of the farming kids of the group, aren’t you?” She asked, leaning on the table with a pint in hand and gesturing between the two.

“I can’t tell if that’s meant to be an insult,” Nott replied drily, but Caleb just looked thoughtful for a second then turned to her.

“I suppose she’s right. Blumenthal wasn’t so different to Felderwin, though I didn’t come from a farming family.”

Nott groaned loudly. “I did. It was the worst. Early mornings and the constant smell of pig shit. I thought I’d be stuck doing it forever too - thank god I managed to bag someone clever.” She threw a joking wink in Yeza’s direction and he sniggered quietly. Caleb looked as if he was going to say something before she continued, “I mean, most of it sucked. I remember enjoying taking care of the chickens.”

“Oh yes, we kept a few as well. They were good for eggs, but also for when we couldn’t afford to buy meat.” Caleb looked thoughtful, “I remember my father tried to teach me to kill and pluck one once. I told him I didn’t want to hurt Böhnchen and he got angry at me for giving them names. I was… Careful not to get attached after that.”

Nott paused for a moment, concerned but unable to read Caleb’s body language properly, before Yeza prodded her lightly and said, “you’ve never told me about your chickens before.”

She sat for a moment, all the semi-fond memories of chalky corn and feathers coming back to her. “Our chickens were for eggs only, really - way too skinny to eat, so us kids were allowed to give them names. There was Pebbles and Sandals, those two were sisters, then Lady, Flora, Fern, and my personal favourite, Egg.”

“Did you name that one?” Beau questioned, eyebrow raised.

“I was, like, six okay?” Yeza giggled quietly beside her. “But I loved playing with them. Did you know they’re actually really cuddly and nice to pick up? I remember they would always bend down and stay still when I went to grab them.” She grimaced slightly, “I thought it was because they liked me…”

“What was the real reason?” Beau asked. Caleb snorted very quietly,

“Let’s just say my big brother ruined chickens for me forever after he told me. He also told me that eggs are technically just chicken periods, so there’s that too.”

Beau made a sound of abject disgust and turned to Caleb. “Please tell me that’s not true.”

“No that’s fairly accurate.”

“Ugh, god,” she turned and started to walk away, “Caduceus, never make anything for us with eggs ever again, okay?”

Nott laughed and called out, “If I have to bear this knowledge, so do you,” before turning back to the other two. “Hey Yez, since we’re talking about nature and shit, now seems like a good opportunity to ramble about mushrooms to Deucey over there. Catch him while you can, you know?”

His eyes lit up at that, turning to her excitedly, “It’s honestly fascinating. A fungi-based magical signature, like, what even are the properties of those plants? The potential functions I mean –“ she threw him a pointed look, “yes, right, I should go over there and actually find out this stuff.” He smiled sheepishly and hopped down from the table, going to join the others who had apparently migrated to the bar.

Nott turned to Caleb, who still seemed thoughtful. “Are you… Okay?” She questioned carefully.

“Ja, of course. Your husband seems to be a good fellow,” he replied, smiling and genuine.

“Yeah,” she paused, “it’s just you don’t talk about home very often.”

He looked away from her for a moment and replied, quieter now, “no,” another pause, “but it was good. I had a good home.”

They sat in silence for a minute, not awkward, just quiet, before Caleb looked up again, and fixed her with a mirthful smile, “Really though, chicken periods?”

She grinned widely, and fixed him with a mischievous look.

“Don’t even get me started.”

And thus the newly dubbed Farm Kids proceeded to ruin everyone’s lives with all the gross animal facts. (P.S My chickens are terrible and I would die for any one of them.)

She grinned widely, and fixed him with a mischievous look.

“Don’t even get me started.”

And thus the newly dubbed Farm Kids proceeded to ruin everyone’s lives with all the gross animal facts. (P.S My chickens are terrible and I would die for any one of them.)

tags: i just have a lot of feelings about oh so big family clay
only confirmed names are clarabelle and corrin
the others are entirely made up but you can pry the name clementine from my cold dead hands
also gender in the clay family is def all over the place don't @ me
everyone is able to use sign language bc of clem
if you have any clay sibling headcanons come scream into my askbox about it
also i just adopted the headcanon that every member of the family has a name that starts with c
since the dad i also called cornelius
it seems to be a pattern
which is super corny but i'm into it :D
title: Clay Siblings Headcanons
body:
Clarabelle is a Paladin of the Wildmother with an Oath of the Ancients. She’s the eldest sibling and while she keeps them all in line as best as she can she is also very Tired™ of her younger siblings’ bullshit. Is a skilled blacksmith and made her whole family’s armor. Has muscles in places you don’t even know existed.

Celia is a Ranger and Beastmaster and her animal companion is a Giant Badger called Honeydew. Honeydew is mostly specialized on stealing food from Celias’s siblings whenever she wants seconds. Is the second eldest and also tallest of the Clay siblings. Very chubby and soft. Has a talent for languages and driving most of her siblings crazy with her terrible singing voice.

Caduceus is the third in line and he is, apart from his youngest sibling Corrin, the smallest of his family. Something especially Clarabelle and Celia like to remind him and Corrin of. As we all know, Grave Cleric of the Wildmother.

Cormac is a Druid in the Circle of Spores. Much like Caduceus he specializes in decomposition processes of bodies and he used to lead the funeral services alongside his mother before he left his home like Clarabelle and Celia before him. Is a rather timid and introverted guy, but will come out of his shell if you ask about butterflies or astronomy.

Camille stands out as the only Clay sibling without a class. She is as much a passionate scientist as she’s a hobby historian, always reading and learning new things which sets her apart from most of her siblings, many of whom never much cared for reading. Super stubborn, but mostly a giant nerd. Picked the name Camille herself (since Cailan never much felt true to who she is) after one of her favorite historic figures.

Clementine is a Cleric of the Raven Queen and much like her brother she masters the Grave Domain. She was born deaf and uses all her spells with sign language. Is the tea expert in the family as well as a talented artist. Her sketchbooks filled with plants, animals and drawings of all her family were left behind when she followed Clarabelle to find a cure for their home.

Corrin is the baby of the family and also the shortest Clay sibling. They’re a Druid like Cormac but they chose the Circle of the Land (Forest specialization). Corrin has probably climbed every living and dead tree in the near proximity of the Blooming Grove. Always wanted to leave and see the world, but was actually the third to last to actually leave it behind. Curious and caring and oh so much in love with trees and all that grows.
